channel.name: the permutation was not constructed correctly: final value

messages.content: What could possibly cause this? I'm working on our library and it has some rough edges, if i find out anything i'll post it here.
Additional info is that my method executes successfully once while `prove()` and then this error is thrown right away after that
that's something indicating a compile / prove discrepancy I think. something in your code that makes it create a different circuit in 'prove' than the one that was compiled
how can i go about making sure this is the case?
can i take a look at the verification key or circuit digest/hash of the prover somehow?
not that I'm aware of. my (admittedly lame) advice is to comment out part of your code to narrow down which part is causing that error
i have a single offchain state .get call, which means it does two Circuit.witnesses to bring in value + merkle witness etc
Circuit.witnesses are not it, but then i have a bunch of root hash computing to check if my value belongs in a tree and that seems to be the problem
but i rly dont see why, as it runs as it should and appears consistent during tx callback and proving
is there any info on how does compilation work in detail? how can i ensure all my code is ran during compilation so it is included in the verification key?
compilation won't run any `asProver` or `witness` code
so don't do anything in there that later affects your circuit
(that used to be the problem for me at least once)
affects how? are the values that are supposed to return from the witness mocked so that my code can continue?
btw since it doesnt run asProver, it also ignores Circuit.log
the constraint added by `x.assertEquals()` would not be there in compile, but would be in prove

> are the values that are supposed to return from the witness
the values returned from Circuit.witness are in both cases abstract variables
yeah yeah i get the gist i think
In the prover, they are connected to actual values, in compile they aren't
the only thing i do in asProve or witness is just interact with our storage backend
i dont do anything circuit related
but.. can it be that during compile the asProver or within witness is ignored, but during prove the asProver is acting as actual constraints?
no, I hope not 😛
try it out be commenting that part though
let me replace it with something staticky, with no snarky apis under the hood to confirm
i mean, i'd have a pretty difficuult time mocking out a merkle witness to confirm this
What is the original reason to why asProver  is not executed during compile?
it makes the lifecycle a bit inconsistent i think
that's the whole point of asProver. If you want stuff to run during compile, don't use asProver 😄
The prover has additional powers that we don't have during compile: inspect the values of variables
So a primitive like this makes sense, for stuff like Circuit.log
so my issue is caused by a state.get() call, that isnt hidden behind any if statements
i've isolated it completely, made sure it runs during compile and proving
which is kinda wierd... because in my standalone example i have no issues with state get/set
i figured out what the issue was - it was my library again - how unexpected 😄
@maht0rz I'm working on a library, and getting the same error now... Any chance you remember what the issue was here?
mm yeah its most likely a disrepancy between compile/proving time
your â€œcode pathâ€ changes and therefore the proof cannot be generated and it blows up
Is the best advice still to comment stuff out until it works? 😅
yeah, most likely youâ€™ll find some issue in your JS code, like reusing instances created during compilation etc
